choices.text: Heat stable, dialyzable, non protein organic molecules

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a diagnosis of beriberi is found to have a deficiency in thiamine, a vital nutrient in her diet. Her physician explains the significance of thiamine as it relates to her condition and its role in enzymatic processes within the body. Based on this, which of the following best characterizes coenzymes like thiamine in their role in enzymatic reactions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Heat stable, dialyzable, non protein organic molecules

 

Option A.

 

  1. The coenzyme is a non-protein part of the enzyme,
  2. The coenzyme is needed for the biological activity of the enzyme.
  3. They are generally low molecular weight organic substances.
  4. They are mostly heat stable.
  5. The coenzymes combine loosely with the enzyme molecules and both can be separated easily by dialysis.
  6. Once the reaction is completed, the coenzyme is released from the apoenzyme and can bind to another enzyme molecule.
  7. One molecule of the coenzyme is able to convert a large number of substrate molecules with the help of enzyme.
  8. Most of the coenzymes are derivatives of vitamin B-complex group of substances.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Soluble, colloidal, protein molecules: This description more accurately pertains to enzymes themselves, which are proteinaceous in nature, rather than coenzymes. Coenzymes are not proteins but work alongside enzymes.

 

Option C. Structural analog of enzymes: Coenzymes are not structural analogs of enzymes. Instead, they are distinct molecules that assist the catalytic activity of enzymes.

 

Option D. Different forms of enzymes: Coenzymes are not alternative forms of enzymes. They are separate, non-protein entities that bind to enzymes and participate in the catalytic process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coenzymes are typically small, heat-stable, non-protein organic molecules that assist enzymes in catalyzing reactions. They often function as carriers of electrons, atoms, or functional groups. Being dialyzable, they can pass through semi-permeable membranes, which is not characteristic of larger protein molecules.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 49, 50.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic with symptoms resembling pellagra, including dermatitis, ataxia, and neuropsychiatric manifestations. Urine analysis indicates aminoaciduria. Considering the presentation and the urinary findings, this disorder is likely due to a mutation in which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. SLC6A19

 

Option D:

                                                              

  • This disorder is Hartnup’s disease. It is an AR disorder with defective absorption of aromatic amino acids from intestine as well as reabsorption from renal tubules →excretion of amino acids in urine
  • The transporter protein (B0AT1) is encoded by SLC6A19gene
  • Mutation of this gene results in deficiency of this protein either in intestine or renal tubules or both
  • 2 chemically close transcription factors such as ACE 2 in renal & intestinal tubules are required for expression of transporter protein (B0AT1)
  • The pellagra-like symptoms are due to the deficiency of niacin derived from tryptophan. The common manifestations are dermatitis and ataxia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. SLC5A18: This gene is not associated with the described clinical presentation or aminoaciduria related to Hartnup disease.

 

Option B. SLC1A1: While this gene is involved in amino acid transport, mutations in SLC1A1 are not typically linked to the symptoms described here.

 

Option C. SLC7A9: Mutations in this gene are associated with cystinuria, a different condition characterized by defective renal reabsorption of certain amino acids, leading to kidney stone formation, not the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra-like symptoms (dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia), along with aminoaciduria, suggests Hartnup disease, which is characterized by the defective absorption of neutral amino acids, including tryptophan. Hartnup disease is caused by mutations in the SLC6A19 gene, which encodes a transporter protein responsible for the absorption of neutral amino acids in the intestines and kidneys.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 308, 557

questions.text: A neurologist is assessing a teenage girl who has been experiencing fatigue severe enough to prevent her participation in physical education classes. She presents with muscle weakness in her limbs. Lab tests indicate high serum levels of triacylglycerols esterified with long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs) and hypoglycemia. A muscle biopsy shows an abundance of lipid vacuoles. What condition do these clinical findings suggest?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carnitine deficiency

 

Option A:

 

  • Carnitine deficiency is seen in preterm infants, where impaired fatty acid oxidation is noticed → so more glucose is utilized → episodes of hypoglycemia.
  • Primary carnitine deficiency: Classical presentation is hypoketotic hypoglycemic encephalopathy, hepatomegaly, elevated transaminases and ammonia, cardiomyopathy, pericardial effusion, muscle weakness, recurrent episodes of vomiting and diarrhea and infections and hypochromic anemia.
  • The above symptoms are triggered by fasting or viral infections.
  • Secondary carnitine deficiency: c/f-Hypoketotic hypoglycemia in infancy, cardiac and skeletal muscle disease later in life, seizures, apnea and developmental delay.
  • The causes for secondary carnitine deficiency includes organic acidurias, respiratory chain and mitochondrial defects, renal Fanconi syndrome and drug induced (valproic acid, zidovudine).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Affects the de novo synthesis of fatty acids occurs in the cytoplasm with the help of a dimeric multi-enzyme complex termed Fatty acid synthase.

 

Option C: Deficiency of hexosaminidase A leads to accumulation of Ganglioside (GM2). C/F-Mental retardation, Cherry red spot in the macula with Progressive deterioration and death by 3–4 years.

 

Option D: Biotin deficiency includes dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, hyperesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia and hallucinations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical manifestations of carnitine deficiency, including muscle weakness, elevated serum triacylglycerols with LCFAs, hypoglycemia, and lipid accumulation in muscle cells, which reflect the impaired transport of fatty acids into mitochondria for β-oxidation.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:p 224,231.

questions.text: A pediatrician evaluating a 6-month-old girl brought in by her mother. The baby has a history of repeated infections, fever, vomiting, and one seizure episode. There's a significant family history: an elder brother passed away at 3 years old from an undiagnosed condition. The baby appears lethargic and hypotonic, with bilateral nystagmus and a cherry red spot visible in both eyes. A blood examination reveals a decreased level of Hexosaminidase A enzyme, prompting the pediatrician to consider a genetic metabolic disorder. What is the most probable diagnosis for this baby?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tay-Sachs disease

 

Option C:

 

It is a sphingolipidoses or lipid storage disease, due to deficiency of the enzyme Hexosaminidase A. 

 

C/F: Mental retardation, Cherry red spot in the macula and progressive deterioration. Death by 3–4 years

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Gaucher’s disease type 1: Due to deficiency of beta-glucocerebrosidase, C/F: Enlarged liver and spleen, erosion of long bones, no mental retardation, no cherry red spot 

 

Option B: Niemann Pick disease: Due to deficiency of Sphingomyelinase. C/F: Mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness, hepatosplenomegaly with Cherry red spot in macula. Death by 2 years of age.

 

Option D: Sandhoff’s disease: Due to deficiency of Hexosaminidase A and B, c/f: Neurological deficit and MR with cherry red spot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease is a genetic disorder characterized by the absence or insufficient activity of an enzyme called Hexosaminidase A, leading to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside within lysosomes, causing progressive neurological damage.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 68,251.

choices.text: NADPH and cytochrome P-450 play a role
Involves methyl group at omega end

questions.text: Identify an incorrect statement about omega-oxidation of fatty acids:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Takes place in mitochondria

 

Option A:

 

  • It is a minor pathway taking place in microsomes (Endoplasmic reticulum), with the help of hydroxylase enzymes such as NADPH and cytochrome P-450.
  • The CH3 group is converted to CH2OH and oxidized with the help of NAD+ to a COOH group to produce dicarboxylic acids.
  • ω-oxidation becomes important when β-oxidation is defective and dicarboxylic acids (6C and 8C acids) are excreted in urine resulting in dicarboxylic aciduria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Produce dicarboxylic acids: True, omega-oxidation can result in the production of dicarboxylic acids when the omega carbon of fatty acids is oxidized.

 

Option C: NADPH and cytochrome P-450 play a role: True, omega-oxidation involves the cytochrome P-450 enzyme system, which utilizes NADPH as a cofactor.

 

Option D: Involves methyl group at omega end: True, omega-oxidation involves the oxidation of the methyl group at the omega (last carbon) end of fatty acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omega-oxidation of fatty acids takes place primarily in the endoplasmic reticulum of cells, not in mitochondria. This pathway serves as an alternative to the β-oxidation of fatty acids, which occurs in mitochondria and peroxisomes.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 205

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with progressive difficulty in night vision and a recent history of unsteady gait. He reports no significant medical history except for a strict vegetarian diet for many years. Physical examination reveals mild hepatomegaly and decreased ankle reflexes. Laboratory tests show elevated plasma levels of a specific fatty acid. The patient’s condition is suspected to be due to a metabolic disorder affecting fatty acid catabolism:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of phytanic acid

 

Option A:

 

  • Alpha oxidation is removal of 1C at a time from COOH end  and its takes place in peroxisomes
  • Eg: Phytanic acid (require prior α-oxidation to proceed to ß-oxidation).
  • So, defective or lack of alpha oxidation of phytanic acid leads to its accumulation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Formation of dicarboxylic acid: Dicarboxylic acids accumulate as a result of ω-oxidation, which typically occurs when β-oxidation is impaired, not α-oxidation.

 

Option C: Formation of propionyl CoA: Propionyl CoA is a product of the β-oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids, not related to α-oxidation defects.

 

Option D: Formation of acetyl CoA: Acetyl CoA is a product of β-oxidation of fatty acids. Lack of α-oxidation does not directly lead to the formation of acetyl CoA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lack of α-oxidation of fatty acids leads to the accumulation of phytanic acid, a branched-chain fatty acid derived mainly from dietary sources, particularly ruminant fats. Humans lack the enzymes to introduce a double bond in phytanic acid, making α-oxidation necessary for its catabolism. Deficiencies in this pathway, such as in Refsum disease, lead to the accumulation of phytanic acid, which is toxic to cells and can cause symptoms like night blindness, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy.

 

Ref: Harper 30/ed ,pg 231

questions.text: During a rural health camp screening in India, a 6-year-old boy is evaluated for developmental delay and unusual skeletal features. His parents report that he has a history of frequent eye and vision issues. A genetic enzymatic defect is suspected. Which condition is associated with a defect in the enzyme cystathionine synthase?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Homocystinuria

 

Option C:

 

  • Congenital homocystinuria is due to defect in cystathionine beta Synthase deficiency → causes elevated plasma levels of methionine and homocysteine→ increased excretion of methionine and homocysteine in urine and Plasma cysteine is markedly reduced.
  • C/F-Mental retardation, ectopia lentis, thrombosis and charlie chaplin gait.
  • Cyanide-nitroprusside test is positive in urine, urinary excretion of homocysteine is more than 300 mg/24 h and plasma homocysteine and methionine levels are increased.
  • Treatment: Diet low in methionine and rich in cysteine. In few cases, pyridoxal phosphate given in large quantities (500 mg).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hartnup’s disease: Due to defective absorption of aromatic amino acids from intestine as well as reabsorption from renal tubules due to mutation of SLC6A19 gene encodes the transporter protein (B0AT1) seen in Intestine and renal tubules →excretion of amino acids in urine. Due to deficiency of Tryptophan, Niacin is not produced and so, the presentation is similar to Pellagra.

 

Option B. Cystinuria: Due to defect/deficiency of transporter system →patients cannot reabsorb cysteine into their bloodstream  → accumulation of cystine in urine forms crystals and stones → leads to recurrent nephrolithiasis and obstruction of urine flow →c/f- severe, sudden flank pain, blood and WBC in urine, fever, and finally renal failure.

 

Option D. Cystathioninuria: Due to cystathionine deficiency, patient presents with mental retardation, anemia, thrombocytopenia and endocrinopathies. Acquired Cystathioninuria might be due to pyridoxine deficiency, liver diseases and after thyroxine administration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystathionine synthase is an enzyme critical in the metabolism of methionine, converting homocysteine to cystathionine. A deficiency in this enzyme leads to homocystinuria, a disorder characterized by elevated levels of homocysteine, which can result in developmental delay, skeletal abnormalities, and ocular issues.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 221.

choices.text: It is synthesized from lysine and methionine in liver and kidney
It is chemically Beta-hydroxy Gamma-Trimethyl amino butyrate
It is a transporter for short chain fatty acids
Vitamin B12 is essential for its synthesis

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a teenage girl presents with complaints of fatigue and muscle weakness. After conducting lab tests, the diagnosis points towards a carnitine deficiency. The attending physician explains to the girl and her parents about carnitine's role and its characteristics. Which of the following statements about carnitine is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is synthesized from lysine and methionine in the liver and kidney.

 

Options A:

 

  • Long-chain acyl-CoA (or FFA) cannot penetrate the inner membrane of mitochondria, So has to be carried by carnitine transporter (option C).
  • Carnitine is synthesized in the liver and kidneys from lysine and methionine.
  • Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is essential for the synthesis of carnitine (option D).
  • During growth or pregnancy, the requirement of carnitine might exceed its natural production

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. It is chemically Beta-hydroxy Gamma-Trimethyl amino butyrate: This statement is a correct description of the chemical structure of carnitine, indicating that this option could also be considered correct.

 

Option C. It is a transporter for short chain fatty acids: Carnitine primarily facilitates the transport of long-chain fatty acids into mitochondria for oxidation, not short-chain fatty acids.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12 is essential for its synthesis: While vitamin B12 is essential for many metabolic processes, it is not directly involved in the synthesis of carnitine. The synthesis of carnitine requires lysine, methionine, and other cofactors like vitamin C, but not vitamin B12.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carnitine, synthesized from lysine and methionine in the liver and kidneys, is essential for the transport of long-chain fatty acids into mitochondria for β-oxidation

 

Ref: Harper30/e pg 224, Vasudevan 9/ed:p202

questions.text: A 19-year-old African female presents with chronic, mild symptoms of sleeping sickness, persisting over two years. She is treated with difluoromethyl ornithine (DFMO), known for its efficacy against trypanosomiasis. DFMO inhibits the enzyme involved in polyamine synthesis, crucial for the parasite's proliferation. Based on DFMO's mechanism, what type of enzyme inhibition does it exemplify?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Suicidal Inhibition

 

Option A.

 

  • It is also known as mechanism-based inactivation. 
  • Here the inhibitor makes use of the enzyme’s own reaction mechanism to inactivate it.
  • In suicide inhibition, the structural analog is converted to a more effective inhibitor with the help of the enzyme to be inhibited.
  • For example, ornithine decarboxylase (ODC) catalyzes the conversion of ornithine to putrescine which is important for polyamine synthesis. Thus, when the ODC in trypanosoma is inhibited → multiplication of the parasite is arrested. Therefore, inhibitors of ODC enzyme such as difluoromethyl ornithine (DFMO) are found to be effective against trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness).
  • A similar mechanism is noted in the case of Allopurinol which is oxidized by xanthine oxidase to alloxanthine which is a strong inhibitor of xanthine oxidase.
  • The anti-inflammatory action of Aspirin is based on the suicide inhibition. Arachidonic acid is converted to prostaglandin by the enzyme Cyclo-oxygenase.  Aspirin acetylates a serine residue in the active centre of cyclo-oxygenase, thus prostaglandin synthesis is inhibited and so inflammation subsides.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Non-competitive: Cyanide inhibits cytochrome oxidase, Fluoride inhibit enolase thereby consequently the glycolysis, Iodoacetate inhibit enzymes having –SH group in their active centers, BAL (dimercaprol) as an antidote for heavy metal poisoning etc.

 

Option C. Uncompetitive: Inhibition of placental alkaline phosphatase (Regan iso-enzyme) by phenylalanine.

 

Option D. Allosteric: ALA Synthase catalyse the first step in heme biosynthesis and the end product, heme will allosterically inhibit the enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DFMO acts as a suicidal (or suicide) inhibitor by irreversibly binding to and inactivating ornithine decarboxylase, the enzyme responsible for polyamine synthesis essential for the growth and reproduction of Trypanosoma brucei, the parasite causing sleeping sickness. Suicidal inhibitors form a covalent bond with the enzyme, leading to its permanent inactivation.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p78.

questions.text: During a clinical review session, a medical instructor is discussing the various substrates that contribute to the production of glucose through gluconeogenesis. One of the students asks which substrates can be used by the liver to synthesize glucose. The instructor provides a list but includes one substrate that does not contribute to the net synthesis of glucose in gluconeogenesis. Which of the following does not serve as a substrate for net glucose production in gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acetyl CoA

 

Option B:

 

Acetyl CoA cannot contribute to the net synthesis of glucose in gluconeogenesis. While it is a critical molecule in metabolism that enters the citric acid cycle, it does not serve as a gluconeogenic substrate because two carbons are lost as CO2 in the cycle, which precludes the net generation of glucose.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lactate: Lactate can be converted to pyruvate by lactate dehydrogenase and then to glucose via gluconeogenesis.

 

Option C. Pyruvate: Pyruvate is a key gluconeogenic substrate that can be carboxylated to oxaloacetate and eventually converted to glucose.

 

Option D. Alanine: Alanine can undergo transamination to form pyruvate, which can then enter the gluconeogenesis pathway to synthesize glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Substrates for Gluconeogenesis:

 

  • Glucogenic Amino Acid [Alanine is the major contributor]
  • Lactate
  • Glycerol
  • Propionyl CoA.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p185, 186.

questions.text: A teenage boy, self-conscious about his weight, decides to follow a fat-free diet in hopes of improving his physique. After adhering to this dietary regimen for several weeks, he visits a nutritionist for a consultation. Concerned about potential nutritional deficiencies and their impact on lipid metabolism, the nutritionist reviews the boy's diet and decides to assess his body's ability to synthesize various essential lipids that might be affected by his restrictive diet:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prostaglandins

 

Option B:

 

Prostaglandins are synthesized from essential fatty acids, such as arachidonic acid, which are typically obtained from dietary fats. A fat-free diet could lead to a deficiency in essential fatty acids, impacting the body's ability to synthesize prostaglandins. Prostaglandins play various roles in the body, including inflammation, pain modulation, and regulation of blood flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Cholesterol: The body can synthesize cholesterol endogenously, primarily in the liver, and its synthesis is less likely to be directly affected by a fat-free diet.

 

Option C: Glycolipids: Glycolipids are composed of a carbohydrate and a lipid. While dietary fats influence lipid components, the body can also synthesize these from other sources.

 

Option D: Phospholipids: Phospholipids can be synthesized endogenously from glycerol, fatty acids, and phosphate. The body can adapt to variations in dietary fat intake to maintain phospholipid synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prostaglandins are synthesized from arachidonic acid.

  • Arachidonic acid is synthesized from linoleic acid, which is an essential fatty acid supplied from dietary lipids in adequate amounts.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 213-215, 238-240.

choices.text: Different enzymes are found in different site

questions.text: What is this difference in the production of byproducts between beta-oxidation in peroxisomes and that in mitochondria?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) H2O2

 

Option A:

 

Beta-oxidation in peroxisomes differs from mitochondrial beta-oxidation in that it produces hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as a byproduct. Peroxisomal oxidation involves enzymes that transfer electrons directly to oxygen, forming H2O2. This byproduct is then broken down by catalase, which is abundant in peroxisomes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Acetyl CoA: Both peroxisomal and mitochondrial beta-oxidation generate acetyl CoA, so this is not a distinguishing feature.

 

Option C: Different enzymes are found in different sites: While it's true that different enzymes catalyze the steps of beta-oxidation in peroxisomes and mitochondria, this option does not refer to a unique byproduct of the reaction.

 

Option D: NADH is required: NADH is a product of mitochondrial beta-oxidation where it is later used in the electron transport chain to generate ATP. Peroxisomal oxidation does not contribute directly to the electron transport chain and therefore the role of NADH in peroxisomal beta-oxidation is not a key distinguishing feature in the context of byproduct production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A modified beta-oxidation pathway takes place in peroxisomes for fatty Acids > C20, C22 (VLCFs)
  • Oxidation in the Peroxisomes → produces Acetyl CoA and H2O2 (instead of FADH2)
  • No ATP is generated.
  • Further oxidation of Acetyl CoA and Octanoyl CoA takes place in the mitochondria.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 226

questions.text: Which group among the following is responsible for buffering activity of proteins at physiological pH?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Imidazole group

 

Option D:

 

The imidazole group, which is part of the histidine amino acid side chain, has significant buffering capacity at physiological pH (around 7.4). This is because the pKa of the imidazole group is close to the physiological pH, allowing it to effectively donate or accept protons, thereby contributing to buffering.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Sulfhydryl group - Present in cysteine, important for forming disulfide bonds, but not primarily known for buffering.

 

Option B: Indole group - Found in tryptophan, contributes to the protein's structural and functional aspects but lacks significant buffering capacity.

 

Option C: Phenyl group - Part of phenylalanine, contributes to hydrophobic interactions in proteins but does not have a buffering role.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Only amino acid whose pKa value (6.1) is nearby physiological pH (7.4) is Histidine (Imidazole group), due to which it has buffering activity at physiological pH.

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 28.

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a physician evaluates a 7-month-old male infant presented by his mother with concerns about hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and delayed developmental milestones. Suspecting Zellweger syndrome, a peroxisomal disorder, the physician considers the metabolic abnormalities associated with this condition. Which type of fatty acids is known to accumulate in patients with Zellweger syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Very long chain fatty acids                                   

 

Option D:

 

  • Zellweger syndrome is also known as Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome which is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA).
  • Due to mutations in peroxins genes , entry of enzymes into the peroxisomes are denied causing insufficient oxidation of VLCFA leading to its accumulation in CNS causing neurological impairment and death in childhood.
  • It usually presents at birth with profound neurologic impairment and the victims often dying within a year.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: They do not require carnitine for transport across the inner mitochondrial membrane and so are easily oxidized.

 

Option B: Long chain fatty acid accumulation is due to deficiency of long chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase resulting in Nonketotic hypoglycaemia with low carnitine and increased acyl carnitine in plasma.

 

Option C: MCAD accumulation occurs due to deficiency of medium chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase results in acidosis, hyperammonemia, hypoglycaemia and fatty liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome is a peroxisomal disorder characterized by the absence or malfunction of peroxisomes in the cells. One of the key functions of peroxisomes is the β-oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs). In Zellweger syndrome, the inability to metabolize VLCFAs leads to their accumulation in tissues and blood, contributing to the clinical manifestations of the disorder.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 241,614

questions.text: During a biochemistry tutorial, the discussion focuses on the various levels of protein structure and the types of bonds that stabilize each level. A key topic is the primary structure of proteins and the specific type of bond that links amino acids together in a polypeptide chain. Which type of bond is involved in the formation of the primary structure of a protein or polypeptide?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

The primary structure of a protein or polypeptide is formed through peptide bonds, which are a specific type of covalent bond. An amide bond is another term for a peptide bond when referring to its chemical nature. Therefore, all the options accurately describe the bond involved in forming the primary structure of proteins.

 

Bonds responsible for protein structure

 

  • Two types of bonds stabilize protein structure:
     
  1. Covalent (Strong): - Peptide bonds (Amide bond), Disulfide bond (present in all types of protein structures)
  2. Non-covalent (weak): Hydrogen bond, hydrophobic interactions, electrostatic (or ionic or salt) bond, Vander Waals interactions (present in secondary, tertiary and quaternary protein structures)

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: p 34.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is least likely to include neurological symptoms in its classic presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gaucher’s disease

 

Option C:

 

It is a AR disorder.

Due to deficiency of beta-glucocerebrosidase 

 

C/F:

 

Bony pain, pathological fracture

No MR (as beta-glucosylceramide is present in extra neutral tissue)

Hepatosplenomegaly present

Large amounts of glucosylceramide accumulated in macrophages causing: Eccentric nucleus and Cytoplasm’s Crumpled tissue paper appearance 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Tay-Sachs disease: C/F: Neurological Symptoms, Mental retardation. Cherry red spot in the macula. Progressive deterioration No Hepatosplenomegaly.

 

Option B: Niemann-Pick disease: C/F:  Severe CNS damage, mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, Cherry red spot in macula. 

 

Option D: GM1 gangliosidoses: C/F: Mental retardation, hepatomegaly, skeletal deformities. Angiokeratoma. Cherry red spot in the retina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher's disease, particularly type 1, which is the most common form, does not usually present with neurological symptoms. This type is known as non-neuronopathic and primarily affects the spleen, liver, and bones.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 260, 261.

choices.text: Allosteric effectors bind allosteric enzymes at their active sites
Allosteric control with negative feedback is found in many metabolic pathways

questions.text: While studying the regulation of metabolic pathways, a medical student comes across the concept of allosteric control, particularly its role in enzyme activity. Allosteric enzymes have unique characteristics that differentiate them from other enzymes. Which of the following statements accurately describes a property of allosteric enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Allosteric control with negative feedback is found in many metabolic pathways

 

Explanation:

 

Allosteric control with negative feedback is indeed a key regulatory mechanism in many metabolic pathways, making option D correct. In negative feedback allosteric regulation, the end product of a metabolic pathway inhibits an enzyme at an earlier step in the pathway, effectively shutting down production when sufficient product has accumulated. Classic examples include:

  1. Inhibition of phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) by ATP in glycolysis
  2. Inhibition of aspartate transcarbamoylase (ATCase) by CTP in pyrimidine synthesis

 

Other options: 

 

 

Option A. Allosteric effectors bind allosteric enzymes at their active sites: This statement is incorrect. By definition, allosteric effectors bind to sites distinct from the active site, called allosteric sites. The term "allosteric" comes from "allo" (other) and "steric" (space or structure), referring to binding at a site other than the active site. When an allosteric effector binds, it induces a conformational change that alters the activity of the enzyme.

 

Option B. Allosteric enzymes possess secondary structure: This statement is correct but not distinctive. All proteins, including enzymes (allosteric or not), possess secondary structure elements such as alpha helices and beta sheets. This is not a unique characteristic of allosteric enzymes.

 

Option C. Allosteric control is irreversible: This is incorrect. Allosteric regulation is typically reversible, allowing for rapid adaptation to changing cellular conditions. When the concentration of the allosteric effector decreases, the enzyme can return to its original conformation and activity state.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Allosteric enzymes are typically oligomeric proteins with multiple subunits that exhibit cooperativity and sigmoidal kinetics rather than the hyperbolic kinetics of Michaelis-Menten enzymes. Their activity can be modulated by effectors binding at sites distinct from the active site, causing conformational changes that alter the enzyme's catalytic efficiency. This provides a rapid, reversible mechanism for regulating metabolic pathways in response to changing cellular needs, with negative feedback being one of the most common control mechanisms in metabolism.

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 62.

choices.text: It provides an alternative route for N2 excretion through glycine conjugate, hippuric acid
It provides an alternative route for N2 excretion through the N-acetyl glucuronic acid conjugate kynurenine
It neutralized NH3 in both blood as well as urine

questions.text: A 7-month-old baby, with a family history of a urea cycle disorder leading to the death of a sibling at 1 year of age, has been diagnosed with the same condition. What is the rationale for administering benzoic acid to individuals with a urea cycle enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It provides an alternative route for N2 excretion through glycine conjugate, hippuric acid

 

Option A:

                             

  • In urea cycle disorder, amino nitrogen is eliminated in other forms.
  • e.g., as hippuric acid (Benzoyl conjugate of glycine) or phenyl acetyl glutamine.
  • SODIUM BENZOATE (benzoic acid )+ Co A 🡪 Benzoyl co A + glycine (LIVER) 🡪 Benzoyl glycine (HIPPURIC ACID) 🡪 excreted in urine
  • 1 mole of Benzoic acid 🡪 removes 🡪 1 mole of NH3 as glycine
  • SODIUM PHENYLACETATE  + Co A 🡪 SODIUM PHENYL ACETYL CoA + glutamine 🡪 SODIUM PHENYL ACETYL glutamine 🡪 urine
  • 1 mole of PHENYL ACETATE 🡪 removes 🡪 2 moles of NH3 as glutamine

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. It provides an alternative route for nitrogen (N2) excretion through the N-acetyl glucuronic acid conjugate kynurenine: This option is not accurate; kynurenine is a metabolite in the tryptophan degradation pathway and not directly related to the excretion of nitrogen in the context of urea cycle disorders.

 

Option C. It inhibits adenylate deaminase: Adenylate deaminase is not directly relevant to the management of urea cycle disorders or the mechanism of action of benzoic acid in these conditions.

 

Option D. It neutralizes ammonia (NH3) in both blood and urine: Benzoic acid does not neutralize ammonia directly; instead, it provides an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion by forming hippuric acid with glycine.

 

Educational Objective:

           

In urea cycle disorders, benzoic acid provides an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion by forming hippuric acid with glycine, thus reducing ammonia levels in the body. This is crucial for managing hyperammonemia resulting from the body's impaired ability to convert ammonia to urea.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: page 206.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male avid marathon runner presents to the clinic with fatigue and mild disorientation after long training sessions. Laboratory tests indicate slightly elevated ammonia levels. Given the patient's high level of physical activity, the physician considers the main route of ammonia transport from his skeletal muscles to the liver for detoxification. What is the primary form in which ammonia is transported in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alanine

 

Option B:

 

  • Free ammonia is toxic to cells, especially to the brain, hence excess ammonia generated has to be converted to nontoxic form then transported to the liver to enter into the urea cycle.
  • Transport of Ammonia from most of the tissues including the brain: As Glutamine with the help of the enzyme Glutamine Synthetase.
  • Glutamine Synthetase: Ammonia formed in most tissues including the brain is trapped by Glutamate to form Glutamine known as first line trapping of ammonia, requires ATP.
  • Glutaminase: In the liver, glutaminase removes the ammonia from Glutamine, ammonia then enter into urea cycle in the liver
  • Transport of Ammonia from skeletal muscle: From Skeletal Muscle as Alanine

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glutamine: While glutamine is a significant carrier of ammonia, particularly in the brain and other tissues, in the context of intense physical activity, alanine plays a more direct role in transporting ammonia from muscles due to its involvement in the alanine-glucose cycle.

 

Option C. Both A and B: Although glutamine does play a role in ammonia transport, the primary form under conditions of intense physical activity, like marathon running, is alanine due to the rapid generation and need for detoxification of ammonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During intense physical activity, alanine serves as the primary transporter of ammonia from skeletal muscle to the liver for detoxification, via the alanine-glucose cycle


Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 203.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive palmoplantar, nose & pinna pigmentation. Urine sample collected for benedict's test changes to black in the supernatant and the test gives greenish brown precipitate. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alkaptonuria

 

Option B:

 

  • Alkaptonuria is an inborn error of metabolism resulting from homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid (HA), an intermediate in the catabolism of tyrosine.
  • Manifestations include homogentisic aciduria (the urine contains elevated levels of HA, which is oxidized to a dark pigment on standing), arthritis, deposition of black pigment (ochronosis) in cartilage and collagenous tissue.
  • Dietary restriction of phenylalanine and tyrosine will be helpful.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Phenylketonuria: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase; C/F - mentally retardation, agitation, hyperactivity, tremors & convulsions due to interference of phenylalanine with neurotransmitter synthesis & hypopigmentation (inhibition of tyrosinase)

 

Option C. Tyrosinemia type-2: Deficiency of tyrosine transaminase; C/F -Mental retardation, painful corneal lesions, photophobia and keratosis of palmar surface with increased urinary excretion of tyrosine and tyramine.

 

Option D. Argininosuccinic aciduria: Deficiency of argininosuccinate lyase with hyperammonemia and elevated argininosuccinate in CSF and excretion in urine and friable tufted hair (trichorrhexis nodosa).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkaptonuria is a rare metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of homogentisic acid, leading to its oxidation and polymerization, particularly in connective tissues (a condition known as ochronosis), resulting in dark pigmentation. The urine turning black upon standing or after adding an alkalizing agent (in this case, noted during a Benedict's test) is a hallmark sign of this condition.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 304-305, Lippincott 7/e: P 274.

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her 2-month-old infant to the pediatric clinic, reporting that the baby's urine has a distinct cabbage-like odor. This unusual symptom prompts the pediatrician to consider metabolic disorders that could be associated with such an olfactory finding. Based on the described symptom, what is the most probable diagnosis for this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tyrosinemia type 1  

 

Option C:

 

  • Hepatorenal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type I) is an autosomal recessive condition due to a deficiency of enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase.
  • Symptoms usually appear within the first 6 months of life which includes mild mental retardation, Cabbage like odour in urine, hypoglycemia liver failure and finally death occurs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Leucine catabolism defect: Incorrect, as defects in leucine metabolism typically lead to the odor of maple syrup in the urine, not cabbage.

 

Option B. Hawkinsinuria: Incorrect, as this very rare metabolic disorder does not typically present with cabbage odor urine.

 

Option D. Maple syrup urine disease: Incorrect, as the characteristic odor associated with this disorder is sweet or burnt sugar, resembling maple syrup, not cabbage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 304-307, DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 239,240

questions.text: A 62-year-old man from Africa with a history of diabetes presents with severe vomiting, epigastric pain, and confusion. He has been using local herbal remedies to manage his blood sugar for the last 8 months and is concerned about possible overconsumption. On examination, he is comatose, dehydrated, and shows signs of tachycardia and tachypnea. Laboratory tests reveal hypoglycemia at 53 mg/dl and a significant electrolyte imbalance. His urine is positive for a high amount of dicarboxylic acid?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Jamaican Vomiting Sickness

 

Option A:

 

  • Ackee fruit that grows in Jamaica and West Africa contain a toxin called Hypoglycin, which is an inhibitor of fatty acyl CoA dehydrogenase.       
  • It causes severe Hypoglycemia if ingested as it inhibits beta oxidation of fatty acids.
  • Characterized by sudden onset of vomiting 2–6 hrs after ingestion, followed by convulsion, coma and death. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Defective oxidation of VLCFA → accumulation of VLCFA in CNS → causes neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

 Option C:  Carnitine deficiency I  is reported in preterm infants with impaired fatty acid oxidation → more glucose is utilized → hypoglycemia.

 

Option D: Characterized by propionic acidemia, ketoacidosis, and mental abnormalities.

 

Educational objective:

 

Jamaican Vomiting Sickness, which is caused by the ingestion of unripe ackee fruit containing hypoglycin A, a toxin that inhibits fatty acid oxidation. The resulting buildup of dicarboxylic acids in the urine and hypoglycemia due to impaired gluconeogenesis are indicative of this diagnosis.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 219

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has been observing a fast as part of a cultural festival for several days. Despite significantly reduced food intake, he surprisingly reports feeling mentally alert and does not experience any dizziness or significant discomfort typically associated with low blood sugar levels. Intrigued by this adaptation, he visits a healthcare provider for a routine check-up. The provider explains how the body adapts to prolonged fasting by utilizing alternative energy sources to maintain brain function and overall metabolism:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta-hydroxybutyrate.

 

Option C:

 

  • Ketone bodies include acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate and acetone, which are produced by the liver in the fasting state by beta-oxidation of fatty acids. 
  • Then these ketone bodies are released into the bloodstream →used as alternative energy sources for muscle, kidney, and brain. 
  • But the brain specifically requires a small amount of circulating glucose to function and the amount required is reduced when ketone body sources are available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Coenzyme A: It is found in mitochondria and carries acetyl groups into the TCA cycle.

 

Option B: Beta-carotene: It is a vitamin with antioxidant properties.

 

Option D: Apoprotein: It is one of the proteins that hold lipoproteins together.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During prolonged fasting, the body shifts to ketosis, a metabolic state where it uses ketone bodies as an alternative energy source. Beta-hydroxybutyrate is one of the primary ketone bodies produced by the liver from fatty acids in the absence of sufficient glucose. The brain can utilize beta-hydroxybutyrate efficiently in place of glucose, allowing for sustained cognitive function and energy levels despite low blood glucose.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 148-149.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman in India presents with fever, left flank pain radiating to the leg, and acute urinary retention. She has a similar past episode six months ago. On examination, she's tender in the abdominal region and appears anemic. Urinalysis reveals RBCs, pus cells, WBC casts, hexagonal crystals, and amino acids. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cystinuria

 

Option B:

                                

  • Patients with cystinuria cannot reabsorb cysteine into their bloodstream → accumulation of amino acid in urine.
  • As urine becomes more concentrated → excess cysteine forms crystals → lodge in bladder or kidneys.
  • Cystine combines with calcium → forms larger stones → block passage of urine → leads to infections - recurrent nephrolithiasis and obstruction of urine flow → c/f- severe, sudden flank pain, blood and WBC in urine, fever and finally renal failure.
  • Diagnostic tests: Sodium nitroprusside test; X-rays and CT of kidneys – To detect cystine stones.
  • Treatment: To increase cystine excretion by dietary sodium and protein restriction. Also, urine alkalinization improves cysteine solubility and severe cases need surgical intervention.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cystinosis: This is a lysosomal storage disorder with accumulation of excess cystine crystals in eyes and kidneys. Due to mutation in the gene CTNS, which codes for the protein cystinosin, the lysosomal cystine transporter. Symptoms: excessive urination, poor growth, photophobia and renal failure by age 6.

 

Option C. Renal Fanconi syndrome: Caused by Cystinosis with loss of large amounts of salt and other minerals in urine. It is an example of RTA Type 2, characterized by increased urinary excretion of glucose, amino acids, bicarbonate, phosphate and salt wasting.

 

Option D. Cystathioninuria: Due to cystathionase deficiency, presents with mental retardation, anemia, thrombocytopenia and endocrinopathies. Acquired Cystathioninuria might be due to pyridoxine deficiency, liver diseases and after thyroxine administration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of characteristic hexagonal crystals in the urine along with RBCs, pus cells, and WBC casts suggests a stone-forming condition. Cystinuria is a genetic disorder characterized by defective renal tubular reabsorption of certain amino acids including cystine, leading to the formation of cystine stones, which can manifest with urinary retention and flank pain due to obstruction.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 301-302.

questions.text: Which of the following examples best illustrates the concept of enzyme induction?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ALA synthase by barbiturates

 

Option A.

 

  • Induction is effected through the process of derepression. 
  • The inducer will relieve the repression on the operator site and will remove the block on the biosynthesis of the enzyme molecules.
  • E.g: Induction of lactose-utilizing enzymes in the bacteria when the media contains lactose in the absence of glucose.
  • Tryptophan pyrrolase and transaminases are induced by glucocorticoids.
  • Glucokinase is induced by insulin.
  • ALA synthase is induced by barbiturates.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Succinate dehydrogenase by malonate: e.g of competitive inhibition.

 

Option C. Cytochromes by cyanide: e.g of Non-competitive inhibition.

 

Option D. ALA synthase by heme: e.g: of Repression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barbiturates can induce the synthesis of ALA synthase, an enzyme involved in the heme synthesis pathway, by increasing the transcription of its gene. This is an example of enzyme induction where the presence of a compound (barbiturates) increases the production and activity of an enzyme.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 64.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents with a history of mild mental retardation, episodes of vomiting, lethargy, seizures, and hypertonia that were first noted during the initial week of life. Amino acid screening reveals elevated levels of leucine, isoleucine, and valine. Based on these findings, which enzyme is likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase

 

Option A:

            

  • Branched chain amino acids include Valine, leucine, and isoleucine.
  • Deficiency of the branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase results in maple syrup urine disease à accumulation of branched chain ketoacids in blood, urine, and tissues.
  • The urine has the maple syrup odor with development of metabolic acidosis. 
  • Early diagnosis is important to reduce the occurrence of irreversible mental retardation.
  • Treatment: Diet with limited amounts of these amino acids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cystathionine synthase: Congenital homocystinuria, C/F-Mental retardation, Ectopia lentis, Thrombosis and Charlie Chaplin gait.

 

Option C. Ornithine transcarbamylase: The only urea cycle disorder with X-linked trait. C/F- Hyperammonaemia, elevated levels of ammonia are associated with high glutamine levels in CSF and blood in the affected child. Mothers also have hyperammonaemia and an aversion to high protein diet.

 

Option D. Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: Methylmalonic Aciduria. C/F- MR, ketosis, hypotonia, Blood-methyl malonic acid is elevated and in urine -methyl maIonic acid and ketone bodies are seen. Treatment –Vitamin B12.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The elevated levels of leucine, isoleucine, and valine indicate Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), which is caused by a deficiency in the branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase complex.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 309-311.

choices.text: A and R both are wrong
A is a wrong but R is a right statement
A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A
A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Cheesy odor in urine is mainly due to isovaleric acid excretion in urine, which is one of the intermediates formed during catabolism of leucine.

Reasoning (R): The defective enzyme in isovaleric acidemia is isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase which is a FAD+ dependent enzyme.

Which of the following is correct regarding the Assertion (A) and Reasoning (R)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A as well as R are right, and R is a correct explanation of A

 

Option D:

 

  • Metabolic disorders of branched-chain amino acid catabolism include hypervalinemia, maple syrup urine disease, intermittent branched-chain ketonuria, isovaleric acidemia, and methylmalonic aciduria.
  • In isovaleric acidemia, due to the defective function of enzyme isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase, the ingestion of protein-rich foods will elevate the diacylation product of isovaleryl-CoA, the isovalerate.
  • C/F: Vomiting, acidosis, coma, and excretion of isovalerate gives cheesy odour to urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isovaleric acidemia (FAD+ dependent enzyme) is a metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation and excretion of isovaleric acid in the urine, which leads to the distinctive "cheesy" odor. This condition is due to a deficiency in isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase, an enzyme crucial for the catabolism of leucine, an essential amino acid.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 309-312.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic with a history of progressive vision loss and a family history of similar symptoms. Genetic testing reveals a mutation affecting the electron transport chain, specifically in the NADH-Q reductase (Complex I). Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this mutation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leber’s optic myopathy

 

Option B:

 

Leber's optic myopathy is associated with mutations affecting mitochondrial function, particularly in components of the electron transport chain like NADH-Q reductase (Complex I). These mutations lead to reduced ATP production and increased oxidative stress, contributing to the degeneration of retinal ganglion cells and optic nerve fibers, resulting in vision loss.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: This is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting motor neurons but is not typically associated with mutations in NADH-Q reductase.

 

Option C. Ragged red fibre disease: Also known as mitochondrial myopathy, this condition is characterized by muscle weakness and the presence of ragged red fibers in muscle biopsies. It can be associated with various mitochondrial defects but is not specifically linked to mutations in NADH-Q reductase.

 

Option D. Duchenne muscular dystrophy: This is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness due to mutations in the dystrophin gene, not directly related to mitochondrial function or NADH-Q reductase mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mutations in mitochondrial DNA causes:

 

  • Lethal infantile mitochondrial ophthalmoplegia
  • Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON)
  • Myoclonic epilepsy
  • Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy lactic acidosis stroke like episodes (MELAS)
  • MERRF
  • Kearns-Sayre syndrome
  • Pearson syndrome
  • Leigh syndrome
  • NARP

 

Mitochondrial DNA Mutations are inherited maternally (mother to all children)

Leber’s hereditary optic myopathy is characterized by blindness in young males and caused by a single base mutation in NADH Coenzyme Q reductase.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 358

questions.text: Identify which of the following enzymes are considered hemoproteins.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both a & b

 

Option C:

 

Both nitric oxide synthase and tryptophan pyrrolase are examples of hemoproteins. Nitric oxide synthase uses heme to catalyze the production of nitric oxide, a critical signaling molecule. Tryptophan pyrrolase, involved in the catabolism of tryptophan, also contains heme as a key component of its active site, enabling its enzymatic function.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nitric oxide synthase: Correct, as it is a hemoprotein involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide.

 

Option B. Tryptophan pyrrolase: Also correct, as it is a hemoprotein participating in the metabolism of tryptophan.

 

Option D. None: Incorrect, as both listed enzymes are hemoproteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heme is present in:

 

  1. Hemoglobin
  2. Myoglobin
  3. Cytochromes
  4. Peroxidase
  5. Catalase
  6. Tryptophan pyrrolase
  7. Nitric oxide synthase

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 270.

questions.text: Match the following enzymes with the pathway they are involved in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

Option A:

 

Explanation:

 

  1. HMG CoA Reductase is a key enzyme in the biosynthesis of cholesterol, catalyzing the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonate, a rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis. Hence, 1-b is correct.

  2. 7-alpha-hydroxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme in the formation of bile acids from cholesterol. It catalyzes the introduction of a hydroxyl group at the 7th position of the steroid nucleus of cholesterol, which is the first step in the classical pathway of bile acid synthesis. Thus, 2-a is correct.

  3. Thiophorase, also known as succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid coenzyme A transferase (SCOT), is involved in ketolysis, particularly in the utilization of ketone bodies by the tissues outside the liver, converting acetoacetate into acetoacetyl-CoA. Therefore, 3-d is accurate.

  4. Carnitine acyl transferase I is a crucial enzyme in the beta-oxidation of fatty acids. It facilitates the transport of fatty acids into the mitochondria for oxidation by converting them into their acyl-carnitine derivatives, which can cross the mitochondrial membrane. Hence, 4-c is correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 172,178

questions.text: How should the following inhibitors be matched with their corresponding complexes or sites?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

Option A:

 

Explanation:

 

  • Cyanide is known to inhibit Complex IV of the electron transport chain by binding to the cytochrome c oxidase, preventing the transfer of electrons to oxygen and thereby halting ATP synthesis.
  • Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of succinate dehydrogenase (Complex II), specifically inhibiting the site between succinate dehydrogenase and Co-Q (coenzyme Q).
  • BAL (British Anti-Lewisite) does not directly inhibit any specific complex within the electron transport chain; thus, its inclusion might be misleading. However, in the context of this question and the available options, it is matched with b, but this is not reflective of its actual function.
  • Chlorpromazine is not a classical inhibitor of the electron transport chain, and its inclusion in this list might not be accurate for educational purposes. However, based on the available options, it is matched with a, Complex I to Co-Q.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 266.

questions.text: Match the following metabolic disorders with their corresponding enzyme defect or deficiency:
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

Option B:

 

 

  • Non-ketotic Hyperglycinemia is characterized by a deficiency in the glycine cleavage system. This enzyme complex is crucial for the breakdown of glycine. A defect here leads to an accumulation of glycine in the body, particularly in the central nervous system, causing severe neurological symptoms.
  • Canavan disease is a rare inherited disorder that causes a buildup of N-acetylaspartic acid in the brain due to a deficiency in the enzyme N-aspartoacylase. This enzyme is crucial for the breakdown of N-acetylaspartic acid. Without it, the myelin sheath, which insulates nerve fibers, cannot be properly maintained.
  • Cystathioninuria is associated with a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionase, which is involved in the conversion of cystathionine to cysteine in the methionine metabolism pathway. A defect in this enzyme leads to an accumulation of cystathionine.
  • Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) is caused by a deficiency in the branched chain ketoacid decarboxylase enzyme complex. This enzyme is vital for the breakdown of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine). A deficiency results in the accumulation of these amino acids and their toxic by-products, giving the urine a sweet odor, reminiscent of maple syrup.  

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 211, 221.

choices.text: It is used to transport NADH from Cytosol to Mitochondria.
It is used to transport NADPH from Cytoplasm to Mitochondria.
Malate get converted to Oxaloacetate and release NADH
Oxaloacetate is reconstituted from Aspartate and α Ketoglutarate

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the malate-aspartate shuttle is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. It is used to transport NADPH from Cytoplasm to Mitochondria.

 

Explanation:

 

The malate-aspartate shuttle is a key biochemical system that allows the transfer of reducing equivalents (NADH) from the cytosol into the mitochondrial matrix, because the inner mitochondrial membrane is impermeable to NADH itself.

 

How it works:

  1. In the cytosol:
    • Oxaloacetate (OAA) is reduced to malate by cytosolic malate dehydrogenase, using NADH.
  2. Malate is transported into the mitochondria.
  3. In the mitochondria:
    • Malate is oxidized back to OAA by mitochondrial malate dehydrogenase, regenerating NADH inside the mitochondria.
  4. OAA is transaminated to aspartate, which can travel back to the cytosol to complete the cycle.

 

Other Option:

 

  • Option A. It is used to transport NADH from Cytosol to Mitochondria:
    True.
    This is the core purpose of the shuttle.
  • Option B. It is used to transport NADPH from Cytoplasm to Mitochondria:
    False.
    The shuttle transports NADH equivalents, not NADPH. NADPH is involved mainly in biosynthesis and antioxidant defenses, not in this shuttle system.
  • Option C. Malate gets converted to Oxaloacetate and releases NADH:
    True.
    Inside mitochondria, malate → OAA + NADH (via malate dehydrogenase).
  • Option D. Oxaloacetate is reconstituted from Aspartate and α-Ketoglutarate:
    True.
    Aspartate + α-KG ↔ OAA + glutamate (via transamination).

 

Educational Objectives:

 

  • The malate-aspartate shuttle transfers cytosolic NADH equivalents into the mitochondria for oxidative phosphorylation.
  • It operates via a series of reversible reactions, involving:
    • Oxaloacetate → Malate (reduced by cytosolic NADH)
    • Malate transport into mitochondria
    • Malate → Oxaloacetate (regenerates NADH in matrix)
    • Transamination of oxaloacetate+ Glutamate  ↔ aspartate + α-ketoglutarate

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 219.

choices.text: Deficiency of G6PD occurs only in red blood cells.
The HMP shunt involves one reversible reductive reaction followed by a series of phosphorylated reactions and sugar inter conversions.
Deficiency of G6PD → inability to keep glutathione in reduced functional form.
The reduced NADPH formed during the shunt is utilized in fatty acid oxidation.

questions.text: A child was recently diagnosed with G6PD deficiency. Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) catalyzes the regulatory step in the HMP shunt. Which is the correct statement about G6PD and HMP shunt?
questions.solution:
Ans. C)  Deficiency of G6PD → inability to keep glutathione in reduced functional form.        

 

Option C:

                                                                            

  • Reduced glutathione is an important antioxidant.
  • The NADPH is supplied by the oxidative reactions of the pentose phosphate pathway which is regulated by the availability of NADPH at the G6PD-catalyzed step.
  • The pathway involves two irreversible oxidative reactions, each of which generates NADPH. The NADPH is used in fatty acid synthesis, steroid hormone and cholesterol synthesis.
     

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Deficiency of G6PD occurs only in red blood cells: The oxidative phase of the pathway is seen in Liver, Adipose tissue, Adrenal cortex, Testes and ovaries, RBCs and Lens of eye. The non-oxidative phase is present in all tissues.

 

Option B. The HMP shunt involves one reversible reductive reaction followed by a series of phosphorylated reactions and sugar inter conversions: involves two irreversible oxidative reactions

 

Option D.  The reduced NADPH formed during the shunt is utilized in fatty acid oxidation: used in fatty acid synthesis, steroid hormone, and cholesterol synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD is an enzyme in the hexose monophosphate shunt that is responsible for the production of NADPH. NADPH is crucial for maintaining the reduced form of glutathione, a critical antioxidant in cells. In G6PD deficiency, the reduced production of NADPH leads to a reduced ability to maintain glutathione in its reduced form, making red blood cells more susceptible to oxidative damage.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 196-200.

choices.text: Bypassing carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (CPS-II)

questions.text: A neonate is lethargic, drowsy, and irritable with blood analysis showing hyperammonemia and orotic aciduria. Considering this patient, orotic acid levels are high due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bypassing carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (CPS-II)

 

Option C:

 

  • The rate limiting step for de novo pyrimidine synthesis is carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II (CPS-II), which produces carbamoyl phosphate in the cytoplasm.
  • In an OTC deficiency, the carbamoyl phosphate produced in the mitochondria leaks into the cytoplasm leading to orotic acid synthesis as the regulated step of the pathway is being bypassed.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A, Option B. The elevated ammonia is not a substrate of CPS-II and which glutamine is also elevated and is a substrate of CPS-II, higher glutamine concentrations will not overcome enzyme inhibition by its allosteric inhibitor, UTP.

 

Option D. Aspartate transcarbamoylase is the regulated step of pyrimidine biosynthesis in many prokaryotic cells, but not in humans. This step is necessary for pyrimidines to be synthesized starting with carbamoyl phosphate.

 

Educational Objective:


Hyperammonemia and orotic aciduria in a neonate suggest a urea cycle defect, particularly ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency, leading to the diversion of carbamoyl phosphate into the pyrimidine synthesis pathway and bypassing CPS-II.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 205.

choices.text: Due to deficiency of enzyme Phenylalanine Hydroxylase
Mental retardation is a potential complication
Presence of a white patch of hair is due to a deficiency in tryptophan
Phenylacetate is found in the urine

questions.text: During a routine neonatal examination, a newborn girl is noted to have blue eyes, blond hair, and fair skin. A Guthrie test is performed, yielding positive results. Among the following statements related to this case, which one is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Presence of a white patch of hair is due to a deficiency in tryptophan

 

Option C:

 

This case describes a newborn with classic physical features of phenylketonuria (PKU) - blue eyes, blond hair, and fair skin - who has tested positive on the Guthrie test, a screening test for elevated phenylalanine levels.

 

Statement C is incorrect because the hypopigmentation (lighter hair and skin) seen in PKU is not related to tryptophan deficiency. Rather, it results from Reduced tyrosine availability (since phenylalanine cannot be converted to tyrosine)

Tryptophan is an essential amino acid involved in serotonin synthesis, but it does not play a direct role in the pigmentation pathways affected in PKU.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Due to deficiency of enzyme Phenylalanine Hydroxylase: This statement is true. PKU is caused by mutations in the gene encoding phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH), which normally converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. Without functional PAH, phenylalanine accumulates to toxic levels in the body.

 

Option B. Mental retardation is a potential complication: This statement is true. Untreated PKU can lead to significant intellectual disability due to the neurotoxic effects of elevated phenylalanine and its metabolites. Early diagnosis and dietary management can prevent this outcome.

 

Option D. Phenylacetate is found in the urine: This statement is true. In PKU, the excess phenylalanine is metabolized through alternative pathways, producing phenylketones including phenylpyruvate, phenyllactate, and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine. The presence of these compounds gives PKU its name and produces the characteristic "musty" or "mousy" odor.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Phenylketonuria results from phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency, causing elevated phenylalanine levels and reduced tyrosine. The hypopigmentation seen in PKU patients is due to impaired melanin synthesis from reduced tyrosine availability—not from tryptophan deficiency. Early detection through newborn screening and prompt dietary management are essential to prevent the neurological sequelae of this inborn error of metabolism.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 304-306

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with intermittent involuntary tremors in his left hand, difficulty feeding himself, walking challenges, and poor gait coordination for the past month. Upon examination, he exhibits a shuffling gait and resting tremors, but cognitive functions remain intact. Diagnosed with Parkinson's disease, he is prescribed levodopa. Which metabolic pathway is primarily affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tyrosine

 

Option C:

 

 

  • Parkinson disease is due to defective dopamine synthesis in the substania nigra →dopamine content in brain is reduced.
  • Dopamine is derived from tyrosine.
  • Treatment with L-DOPA in the initial stages of the disease provides relief from the symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Phenylalanine: While phenylalanine is a precursor to tyrosine, the direct pathway affected in Parkinson's disease is the tyrosine to dopamine pathway.

 

Option B. Tryptophan: Involved in the synthesis of serotonin and melatonin, not directly implicated in Parkinson's disease.

 

Option D. Histidine: Involved in the synthesis of histamine and is not directly related to the dopaminergic pathways affected in Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parkinson's disease is associated with the dopaminergic pathway, where tyrosine is a key precursor in the synthesis of dopamine. Levodopa, a precursor of dopamine, is used to increase dopamine levels in the brain, addressing the dopamine deficiency that characterizes Parkinson's disease.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 235.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child presents with a 5-month history of eye ulceration and thick, rough, patchy skin on the palms and feet. Examination reveals dendritic corneal ulceration unresponsive to antiviral treatment and keratosis on the palms and plantar surfaces. Laboratory tests show increased levels of tyrosine in blood and urine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Tyrosinemia type 2

 

Option A:

 

  • Tyrosinemia type-2/Oculocutaneous Tyrosinemia/Richner-Hanhart Syndrome is due to deficiency of Tyrosine Transaminase.
  • C/F- Mental retardation, keratosis of palmar surface, painful corneal lesions and photophobia with increased excretion of tyrosine and tyramine in urine.
  • A diet low in protein is advised.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hepatorenal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type I) is due to a deficiency of enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. C/F: mild mental retardation, Cabbage like odour in urine, hypoglycemia liver failure and finally death occurs

 

Option C. Neonatal Tyrosinemia (Tyrosinemia Type III) due to the absence of the enzyme para-hydroxyphenylpyruvate hydroxylase, which causes transient hypertyrosinemia in the newborn, and this will respond to ascorbic acid and dietary protein restriction.

 

Option D. Hawkinsinuria is due to dysfunction of p-HPPA oxidase, characterized by excretion of hawkinsin in urine, a derivative of p-HPPA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tyrosinemia type-2, also known as Richner-Hanhart syndrome, is characterized by elevated levels of tyrosine which can lead to eye problems (like corneal ulcers), skin disorders (such as palmoplantar keratosis), and sometimes intellectual disability.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 239.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with a constellation of symptoms including flushing, a non-healing ulcer, diarrhea, and episodes of bronchospasm. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of 5-Hydroxyindoleacetic Acid (5-HIAA) in her blood. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Carcinoid syndrome  

 

Option C:

                                        

  • Carcinoid syndrome is due to excessive production of serotonin resulting from tumours of argentaffin cells in GIT.
  • C/F: flushing, sweating, intermittent diarrhoea and fluctuating hypertension.
  • 5-HIAA is the catabolic end product of serotonin. So its level is increased in this disorder 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A Glucagonoma: Is a rare tumour of pancreatic alpha cells, resulting in overproduction of glucagon. It is associated with necrolytic migratory erythema, weight loss and diabetes mellitus.

 

 Option B. Gastrinoma: Is a gastrin secreting tumour of pancreas resulting in Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, where there is no feedback regulation of gastrin secretion causing very high level of gastric acid output along with high serum gastrin levels.

 

Option D. Insulinoma: Is an Insulin secreting tumours characterized by constant high production of insulin (C-peptide) and decreased blood glucose by the tumour cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoid syndrome is characterized by a set of symptoms that include flushing, diarrhea, bronchospasm, and, in some cases, heart valve lesions. These symptoms are caused by the overproduction of serotonin by carcinoid tumors, most commonly originating in the gastrointestinal tract or lungs. Elevated levels of 5-Hydroxyindoleacetic Acid (5-HIAA), a metabolite of serotonin, in the urine or blood are a hallmark finding in carcinoid syndrome and support this diagnosis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: pg 557, DM Vasudevan  9/e: p 241-242

questions.text: A pediatrician is evaluating a newborn for potential metabolic disorders due to some concerning symptoms. Given the suspicion of phenylketonuria (PKU) among other metabolic conditions, the pediatrician considers the most effective screening method to identify such diseases in their early stages. Which screening test is considered the gold standard for detecting PKU and similar metabolic disorders in newborns?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tandem Mass spectrometry  

 

Option D:

                                                       

  • Blood is obtained by heel-stick → applied to a filter-paper with four to six circles approximately 1 cm in diameter à allowed to dry and sent to a screening laboratory for further analysis.
  • Small circles of blood-soaked filter paper are punched out and metabolites are extracted with organic solvents.
  • Gold standard screening test for metabolic diseases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Western blot: Incorrect, as it's primarily used for protein analysis and not typically for newborn metabolic screening.

 

Option B. Electrophoresis: Incorrect, while it can separate molecules based on size and charge, it's not as comprehensive or specific for metabolic disorders as tandem mass spectrometry.

 

Option C. FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization): Incorrect, as FISH is mainly used for detecting chromosomal abnormalities and gene mapping, not for screening metabolic disorders like PKU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem Mass Spectrometry (MS/MS) is widely used in newborn screening programs for the detection of various metabolic disorders, including phenylketonuria (PKU). This method allows for the simultaneous screening of multiple disorders by analyzing patterns of specific metabolites in a small blood sample, usually obtained via heel prick in newborns. Its sensitivity and specificity make it an ideal choice for early detection.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e :p 427

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes fits the definition of a lyase?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aldolase B

 

Option A.

 

Aldolase B is a type of lyase that specifically catalyzes the cleavage of fructose 1,6-bisphosphate into glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate and dihydroxyacetone phosphate in the glycolysis pathway. This reaction involves the breaking of a C-C bond, which is characteristic of lyase activity.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option B. Lactate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is classified as an oxidoreductase. It catalyzes the interconversion of pyruvate and lactate with concomitant interconversion of NADH and NAD+.

 

Option C. Acetylcholine esterase: This enzyme is a hydrolase, not a lyase. It catalyzes the hydrolysis of acetylcholine into choline and acetate, a critical reaction in the function of the nervous system.

 

Option D. Acetyl CoA carboxylase: This enzyme is a ligase (more specifically, a biotin-dependent carboxylase). It catalyzes the ATP-dependent carboxylation of acetyl-CoA to produce malonyl-CoA, a key step in fatty acid synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Some examples of Lyases are:

 

  1. HMG CoA Lyase
  2. Argininosuccinate Lyase
  3. ATP Citrate Lyase
  4. Aldolase
  5. Fumarase

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 49.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with progressive involuntary movements in her right hand and visual difficulties noted over the past year. Blood work reveals elevated serum homocysteine with normal liver, renal, thyroid function tests, and electrolytes. She responds favorably to high-dose pyridoxine and a methionine-restricted diet, with a noted improvement in dystonic movements after three months. What condition is most likely affecting this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Classical Homocystinuria

 

Option C:

 

  • Classical homocystinuria is due to the deficiency of the enzyme, cystathionine beta Synthase.
  • Clinical features: failure to thrive, developmental delay, ectopia lentis, severe myopia, cataracts, retinal detachment, and optic atrophy. Progressive mental retardation, skeletal abnormalities may resemble Marfan syndrome. Thromboembolic episodes may be seen at any age. Elevated homocysteine level is a risk factor for CAD, CVA, PAD and DVT.
  • During pregnancy, it causes neural tube defects and pre-eclampsia.
  • Diagnosis: amino acid screen in urine and blood (homocysteine and methionine are elevated, cystine will be low), liver biopsy, enzyme assay, skeletal X-ray, skin fibroblast enzyme assay, standard ophthalmic testing, and genetic testing.
  • Treatment with high doses of pyridoxine, folic acid, B12 and betaine reduces homocysteine levels.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hartnup’s disease: Due to defective absorption of aromatic amino acids from intestine as well as reabsorption from renal tubules →excretion of amino acids in urine.

 

Option B. Cystinuria: Due to defect/deficiency of transporter system →patients cannot reabsorb cysteine into their bloodstream →accumulation of cystine in urine forms stones →leads to recurrent nephrolithiasis, obstruction, and finally renal failure.

 

Option D. Cystathioninuria: Due to cystathionase deficiency, patient presents with mental retardation, anemia, thrombocytopenia and endocrinopathies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classical homocystinuria is often due to a deficiency in the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase, leading to elevated homocysteine levels. Treatment with high-dose pyridoxine (vitamin B6), a cofactor for the enzyme, can improve symptoms, and a methionine-restricted diet can help manage homocysteine levels. The improvement in dystonia with treatment supports this diagnosis.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 221.

choices.text: Increased tyrosinase activity will be observed in melanocytes
Mental retardation is the main characteristic feature in albinism
Skin has high pigmentation in albinism

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant with pale skin and blonde hair is presented to the pediatric outpatient department by her parents. The infant has two siblings with complete albinism, while both parents are phenotypically normal. Based on this family history and the clinical presentation, which statement is correct regarding albinism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It results in photophobia

 

Option B:

 

  • Albinism is an AR disease with completely absence of tyrosinase →defective synthesis of melanin.
  • The ocular fundus is hypopigmented and the iris would be gray or red with photophobia, nystagmus and decreased visual acuity.
  • The skin has low pigmentation, is sensitive to UV-rays with presence of nevi and melanomas.
  • Hair of the patient is also white.
  • NO Mental retardation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increased tyrosinase activity: Incorrect. Albinism is usually associated with decreased or absent activity of tyrosinase in melanocytes, not increased activity.

 

Option C. Mental retardation: Incorrect. Albinism does not inherently affect cognitive function; mental retardation is not a characteristic feature of albinism.

 

Option D. Skin has high pigmentation: Incorrect. Albinism is defined by reduced or absent pigmentation in the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Albinism is characterized by a deficiency or absence of melanin pigmentation and can often result in photophobia due to the lack of melanin in the iris and retinal pigment epithelium. This causes increased light penetration into the eye, leading to discomfort in bright environments.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/ed: p 238.

questions.text: Among the listed enzymes, which one is NOT typically considered a non-functional enzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lipoprotein lipase

 

Explanation:

 

Enzymes found in the plasma can be classified into two types:

 

Non-functional (plasma marker) enzymes:

  • These do not perform any physiological function in plasma.
  • Their presence in serum is typically due to cell damage or turnover.
