  • Elevated levels help identify tissue injury or disease.
  • Examples:
    • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) – bone and liver disorders
    • Acid phosphatase – prostate conditions
    • Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) – hepatobiliary dysfunction
    • LDH, CK, AST – used as diagnostic markers

 

Functional (plasma active) enzymes:

  • These perform essential metabolic functions within the circulation.
  • They are actively secreted into plasma to carry out physiological roles.

 

Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is a classic functional enzyme:

  • It hydrolyzes triglycerides in chylomicrons and VLDL into free fatty acids and glycerol.
  • Plays a critical role in lipid metabolism and energy distribution.

 

Other Options:

  • Alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
    → Non-functional enzyme; diagnostic marker for bone and hepatobiliary diseases.
  • Acid phosphatase
    → Non-functional; historically used to detect prostate cancer.
  • Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)
    → Non-functional; useful in assessing alcoholic liver disease and cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lipoprotein lipase is a functional plasma enzyme, directly involved in lipid metabolism.
  • In contrast, non-functional enzymes like ALP, ACP, GGT do not have roles in the plasma but serve as important clinical markers of tissue damage.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 301.

questions.text: During a case discussion, involving altered immune and neurological functions, focusing on a specific metabolic pathway. The students are asked to identify the precursor amino acid in the kynurenine pathway, known to impact both neurological and immune responses. Which amino acid is focus of this discussion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tryptophan

 

Option B:

 

  • Major metabolic fate of Tryptophan is to be oxidized by tryptophan pyrrolase / Tryptophan Oxygenase, which is a dioxygenase and an Iron Porphyrin Metalloprotein.
  • Then forms kynurenine as given in the pathway.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Phenylalanine: This amino acid is primarily converted into tyrosine, not kynurenine.

 

Option C. Tyrosine: Tyrosine is a precursor for several important substances, including dopamine, epinephrine, and norepinephrine, but not kynurenine.

 

Option D. Histidine: Histidine is metabolized into histamine, among other products, and does not lead to kynurenine formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kynurenine is formed from the catabolism of tryptophan via the kynurenine pathway. This pathway is crucial not only for the degradation of tryptophan but also for the production of several important metabolites, including nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+), which plays a vital role in cellular energy metabolism and cellular signaling processes.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 240.

questions.text: A team of endocrinologists is conducting a study on the regulation of fat metabolism by various hormones. Their research focuses on the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) in adipose tissue, a crucial enzyme in the mobilization of stored fats. Through their investigations, they aim to determine which hormone does not stimulate an increase in HSL activity. Which hormone is NOT associated with an increase in the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase in adipose tissue?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Insulin

 

Option D:

 

Insulin Favours Lipogenesis

 

  • Insulin increases the uptake of glucose by adipocytes and increases the activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase, acetyl CoA carboxylase and glycerol phosphate acyl transferase
  • But Insulin suppresses hormone sensitive lipase.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Adrenaline: This hormone activates hormone-sensitive lipase via the cAMP signaling pathway, leading to increased lipolysis.

 

Option B: Growth hormone: Growth hormone can stimulate lipolysis in adipose tissue, partly by increasing HSL activity.

 

Option C: Corticosteroids: Corticosteroids can also promote lipolysis, although their effect may be more complex and context-dependent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Insulin is known to inhibit the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) in adipose tissue.
  • HSL plays a key role in the hydrolysis of stored triglycerides into free fatty acids and glycerol, a process that is suppressed by insulin.
  • Insulin promotes fat storage by inhibiting lipolysis, in contrast to hormones like adrenaline, growth hormone, and corticosteroids, which stimulate HSL activity and promote fat breakdown.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 159

questions.text: A newborn screening reveals elevated levels of branched-chain amino acids and their α-ketoacid derivatives, along with lactic acidosis. Which enzyme is likely affected by this disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase

 

Option A:

 

  • The child has a mutation in the shared E3 submit of pyruvate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase and the branched chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase.
  • All the three reactions are oxidative decarboxylation reactions which utilize a three-component enzyme complex, designated as E1, E2 and E3.
  • The E1 subunit:  Binds thiamine pyrophosphate and catalyzes the decarboxylation reaction.
  • The E2 subunit: It is a trans acylase and involved in the oxidation-reduction part of the reaction.
  • The E3 subunit: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase is shared among all three enzymes and a mutation in this subunit will affect the activity of all three enzymes.
  • This subunit reduces NAD + using electrons obtained from reduced lipoic acid.
  • The problem is solved by recognising that lactic acidosis occurs when pyruvate dehydrogenase was defective.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: While part of the Krebs cycle, this enzyme is less directly impacted by the conditions described in the scenario.

 

Option C. Malate dehydrogenase: Also part of the Krebs cycle, but the scenario specifically suggests an issue more closely related to α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase due to the link with branched-chain amino acid metabolism.

 

Option D. Succinate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of both the Krebs cycle and the electron transport chain, but the described symptoms do not specifically implicate this enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elevated branched-chain amino acids and their derivatives, along with lactic acidosis, suggest mitochondrial disruption, potentially due to Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), affecting the Krebs cycle. Excess NADH from MSUD inhibits key enzymes like α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, leading to lactic acidosis by diverting pyruvate to lactate.

 

Ref:  DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 208, 230, 431.

questions.text: One specialized organ in mammals has a unique adaptation that allows it to utilize fuel oxidation not primarily for ATP production but for the generation of heat, aiding in thermoregulation. Which of the following is this specialized organ?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brown adipose tissue

 

Option C:

 

Brown adipose tissue gets its colour due to the high density of mitochondria in the individual adipose cells and new-born babies have it in their neck and upper back which serves the function of non-shivering thermogenesis.

 

Brown adipose tissue contains thermogenin, which is a physiological uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation.

 

The muscle contractions take place in the process of shivering not only generate ATP but also produce heat.

 

Non-shivering thermogenesis is a hormonal stimulus for heat generation without the associated muscle contractions of shivering.

 

This process in brown fat is initiated by the release of free fatty acids from the triglycerides stored in the adipose cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: The adrenal gland is involved in hormone production, including stress and metabolic hormones, but it is not primarily associated with heat generation.

 

Option B: Skeletal muscle can produce heat through shivering thermogenesis, where muscle contractions generate heat, but this is not its primary function.

 

Option D: The heart's primary function is to pump blood throughout the body, and while it does produce heat as a byproduct of its metabolic activities, it is not specialized for heat production like brown adipose tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brown adipose tissue is the specialized organ in mammals designed for heat production through non-shivering thermogenesis, emphasizing its role in thermoregulation and energy metabolism.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 162, 267.

questions.text: The diagram below represents the various fates of pyruvate. Which letter on the diagram shows the reaction requiring biotin as a cofactor and is activated by acetylcoenzyme A?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C    

 

Option B:  

              

  • Pyruvate carboxylase, a mitochondrial enzyme of gluconeogenesis, requires biotin and ATP for its essential function
  • Pyruvate enters the mitochondrion and is carboxylated to oxaloacetate. This reaction is important in maintaining an adequate level of oxaloacetate for the condensation reaction with acetylCoA .
  • If acetyl-CoA accumulates, it acts as both an allosteric activator of pyruvate carboxylase and an inhibitor of pyruvate dehydrogenase, thus ensuring a supply of oxaloacetate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. B: Denotes PDH present in mitochondria, which oxidatively decarboxylates pyruvate to acetyl CoA.

 

Option C. D: Denotes ALT. Alanine is formed by transamination of pyruvate by the enzyme alanine aminotransferase (ALT), which requires PLP.

Pyruvate + Glutamate → Alanine + alpha ketoglutarate

 

Option D. A: Pyruvate kinase dephosphorylates phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate, which is a substrate level key glycolytic enzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The role of biotin is a cofactor in the carboxylation reaction catalyzed by pyruvate carboxylase and how acetyl-CoA serves as an allosteric activator of the enzyme, linking the state of cellular energy to gluconeogenesis.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 165,166.

questions.text: A 28-year-old marathon runner visits a sports medicine clinic complaining of prolonged recovery times after long training sessions. She's interested in optimizing her nutrition to enhance muscle repair and overall performance. Her recent blood work showed slightly elevated homocysteine levels. The physician decides to focus on her dietary intake, specifically the vitamins involved in the metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids, which are crucial for muscle recovery. Which vitamins should the physician consider crucial in this metabolic pathway to address the runner's concerns and blood work findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Both a and b

 

Option D:

 

Vitamins in the metabolism of Sulfur containing Amino Acids

 

  • Three vitamins needed are Vitamin B12, Folic acid and Vitamin B6.
  • Vitamin B12 and Folic acid for Methionine Synthase reaction.
  • Vitamin B6 for Cystathionine Beta Synthase (Transsulfuration reaction) and Cystathionase.

 

Note - Vitamin K is not directly involved in the metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 and folic acid play pivotal roles in the metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids. Vitamin B12 is involved in the conversion of homocysteine to methionine, while folic acid is essential for the remethylation of homocysteine, also contributing to its conversion back to methionine. These processes are crucial for maintaining low levels of homocysteine, high levels of which are associated with cardiovascular diseases.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 216.
